"June loth. Ban Mordin—Swede—entered ward 17—he is a
clerk—last from Cbicago—five months in New Orleans. This man
was entirely delirious, and presented all the symptoms of delirium
tremens—fever arose on the day after his admission, and on the 19th
he died of as pure black vomit as was ever seen.
"June 17th. Herman Ferringer—German—aged 20 years—last
from Chicago—in New Orleans six months—entered ward 22—
occupation, brewer—presented all the symptoms of "pernicious
intermittent fever," but died on the lllth will, some symptoms of
yellow fever—so decided as to lead to the prediction that black
vomit would be found in the stomach after death. The autopsy
revealed genuine brack vomit in the stomach.
"Health of our City—July 25th, 1855.—The 25th of July
has arrived, and we find ourselves again called on to render an
Our last report was anything but a flattering one, and we had hoped
to be able, this time, to present our readers a more agreeable picture. To some extent these hopes have been realized, though there
cause for solf-gratulation. Our last report showed us to be just
emerging from an epidemic of cholera, which had, in a few short
weeks, killed near eight hundred of our citizens, in addition to a
large mortality by other diseases. Since the issue of that report,
the number of deaths by this disease have .gradually declined, until
it has almost disappeared—there being but 8 deaths reported for
nounced the appearance of yellow fever here by reports of ten un-
